body: Thanks for the update @yanghua, I'll merge this.
Thanks for the review. Merging.

Hi @dawidwys, I addressed your last comments.
Also, we now have a `TypeSerializerSnapshotMigrationITCase` that verifies restoring from savepoints which used `TypeSerializerConfigSnapshot` works correctly when changing to directly implement `TypeSerializerSnapshot`.

The savepoints were written by their respective branches, e.g. `release-1.3` for the 1.3 savepoint.
LGTM, merging.

Thanks @isunjin, @gaoyunhaii, @pnowojski for your reviews - and sorry @gaoyunhaii for taking over - I wanted to verify that this is indeed fixing the problems I've seen and needed the patch urgently - to avoid double work, I created the PR immediately.

I integrated your comments and will merge once a new Travis build gives its ok.
@igalshilman I integrated your comments and Travis gives green light. Let me know what you think.
+1, merging

Thanks @bmeriaux for the contribution. For the future before you start working on some issue please agree on the corresponding JIRA (I've seen it is assigned to someone else).

+1, merging
+1 LGTM, nice testing!
Hi Sorry I was off grid for a bit. Thanks @bmeriaux for picking up my slack! :)
Is a chance that it will make it into 1.7?
Hi @pnowojski and @dawidwys, This PR takes a long time, can you help to review it? Thanks.

@alexeyt820 thanks for paying attention to this PR. I am trying to fix some test issue. Based on the community's efficiency, It may not catch up with the time point of releasing 1.7. I will try my best to fix these test issues as soon as possible.

@fhueske 
Thanks for reviewing this PR. I can't agree more on offering a similar experience for both input formats (Parquet and ORC). I will resolve your comments in code tonight.

Best Regards
Peter Huang

Hi,
I need you advice on the inheritance with `CassandraOutputFormatBase`, because `CassandraOutputFormatBase` constructor need an insert query, which i do not have in the `CassandraPojoOutputFormat`.
I choose the duplication option.
What do you think about pull up Row/Tuple specific code to their classes and refactor the `CassandraOutputFormatBase` with only common code? if any user have made some inheritence of the base class it will break, is it considered as a breaking change ?
@xccui Thank you very much for your time and effort. I also have a PR #6432  about `ASCII/CHR`. When you have time, can you help with the review?

Thanks for efficient reviews! @NicoK @pnowojski 

I already updated the codes based on above comments except the additional missing tests. I find there only exists one test currently related with `BufferPoolOwner` whose behavior is throwing exception when calling release memory, so the normal behavior of `BufferPoolOwner` is also missing besides with different `ResultPartitionType`. 

But I think it is another topic and I want to add more tests for it in a separate JIRA which I will create later. The motivation of this PR only moves the `BufferPoolOwner` into the constructor of `LocalBufferPool` and it does not effect the previous behaviors. What do you think?

Thanks @dawidwys.
I'll address your last comments, rebase on master and after Travis gives green, proceed to merge this :)

@tzulitai 
Thank you for reviewing.

@fhueske 
Resolved most of your comments. The major blocker is probably the splittable processing of Parquet files. It will probably have a big change on the PR and more test case to cover. Given this is already a big PR, how about let me work on the improvement on another PR?
@yanghua What is the problem with the failing tests? Do you have any idea so far?

@aljoscha some test cases which used kafka-server, failed with this exception : 

```
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/slf4j/event/Level

	at kafka.utils.CoreUtils$.swallow$default$3(CoreUtils.scala:84)

```

But I checked, the `slf4j-api` exists in the dependencies.

@tzulitai Could you please have a look at the Consumer and Producer constructors to see which ones we'd like to keep? I remember that quite a few of the constructors we have in the older consumers are deprecated and I want to make sure that we only have the good ones here.

@yanghua The internals code (and most of the code in general) you were able to copy from the other connectors, correct? What did you have to adapt to make it work for Kafka 2.0?
@NicoK It's OK, glad that the find helps~ :)

Ignoring the `slf4j` error for now, I see some other errors, for example that `kafka.consumer.ConsumerConfig` cannot be found. The problem is that the packages starting with `kafka.*` are deprecated and have been removed in Kafka 2.0.0. (see here: https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/1.0/core/src/main/scala/kafka/consumer/ConsumerConfig.scala#L26) I think the first step is removing all of those dependencies from the connector-base package. Or, if that is not possible, it might be that Kafka 2.0 can't use the connector-base package.

Hi @yanghua, I think the discussion on the corresponding jira ticket was inconclusive. 

As was discussed recently in the ML, we should first make sure that there is a consensus on the behavior of new features, before even writing the code, therefore I cannot review this PR.

Thanks for the PR @diego-carvallo-tx.
Changes look good, merging this PR.
I don't think we should bring everything to the dev mailing list but a discussion on the Jira ticket would be good. Especially API decisions should be done before implementation, IMO.

@dawidwys and @fhueske Yes, I agree with you. But as far as the current situation is concerned, the Table/SQL module does not respond very quickly (I don't have any complaints), and I have claimed many JIRA issues. For issues with larger changes, I will be more cautious and will discuss and listen to opinions first. But for issues that are not very big, I think maybe the first thing to achieve (even if it's a close plan) is a better choice, which means I have considered the cost of rework.

@fhueske totally agree, what I meant by ML discussion in my previous message, was the review process discussion, where we agreed first we should reach consensus for the design, which is not the case for this PR, as there are still pending questions in the corresponding JIRA.
@dawidwys Can you review this PR?
This definitely looks like something that needs to be fixed. Will take a look.
@zhijiangW I would add more test coverage (at least for the bugs that @NicoK has found) in this PR.

> @yanghua The internals code (and most of the code in general) you were able to copy from the other connectors, correct? What did you have to adapt to make it work for Kafka 2.0?

@aljoscha  In fact this branch evolved from the [previous PR adaptation of kafka 1.0](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/6577). Before that, I used to make it adaptable to kafka 1.0 and all previous tests passed ([of course the test code used some non-public APIs to make some changes](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/6577#issuecomment-414951008)).

This PR upgraded the kafka-related dependencies to 2.0 and then removed its dependency on other kafka connectors.

At present its state is that the source code compilation is no problem, but some tests failed.

Yes, the reason (as I said) is that 1.0 still has the code in those `kafka.consumer...` packages while in 2.0 they are removed.

Most of the Kafka classes used in `KafkaConsumerTestBase` are deprecated and have been removed in Kafka 2.0, that's the problem. Maybe it's enough to copy that to the Kafka 2.0 connector and make it work with Kafka 2.0
Thanks for the update @pnowojski. I will fix the conflicts and merge this.
Thanks a lot @twalthr for polishing this out and merging!
@aljoscha OK, I will try it soon.

@tillrohrmann, thank for the reviewing. So your suggestion is:
1. Move the marking active back to the callback.
2. Mark the slot active if in allocated when submit task.
3. If already active when call back, check the allocation and ignore if the same.
It seems good idea.
@zentol I have already adopted your previous review suggestions. Does it still need other modifications?

@yanghua Actually, I think you can make it work by just removing method `readTopicToList` from `KafkaConsumerTestBase` and and by removing the `kafka.consumer....` imports.

It seems that method is the only one using deprecated API and it's unused...
Thanks @kl0u, LGTM 👍. I will wait for your fix so that Travis would execute the AWS tests.
I believe you haven't addressed my comments regarding the  `JobManagerMetricsITCase`.
oh wait you did, Ill take another look.
Thanks a lot @igalshilman for the review! I will fix this and then merge as soon as Travis gives green.
@aljoscha yes, you are right, I have update the PR.
Merging when Travis gives green light.
@zentol thanks, updated.
@zentol Is there a need for Python-related PR? If not, can we consider closing it?
@twalthr @pnowojski @kl0u Could you help reviewing this PR?
@aljoscha still many failed test cases because of timeout and ClassNotFound.
@pnowojski , I will add the tests in this PR later.
@fhueske Hi, thanks a lot for your review. I have updated the PR.
@pnowojski @NicoK , I already submitted the tests covering the `BufferPoolOwner` with different `ResultPartitionType` in a separate commit. :)
Yes exactly, this would have been the idea. Do you want to update this PR accordingly?
@zentol I've updated the pr based on your comments. Thanks for pointing out `view`, that greatly simplified the implementation.
@tillrohrmann This is very strange, why this PR change causes the yarn test to time out, and some applications cannot reach the RUNNING state.

@yanghua thanks for raising this thread! I think `YARNHighAvailabilityITCase`, `YARNSessionCapacitySchedulerITCase#testClientStartup` and `YARNSessionCapacitySchedulerITCase#testTaskManagerFailure` are ignored by `assumeTrue`.

You remove the `assumeTrue` statement and re-enable them. It looks like unintended. Maybe do some analysis to see if we can remove them as (covered by existing tests/not supported any more) or port them to FLIP-6 code base?
@TisonKun it seems it is not been ignored, it causes my PR failed, see [here](https://travis-ci.org/apache/flink/jobs/439612829).
I try to remove these test methods.

@yanghua According to the slf4j doc `Level` is only available since version `1.7.15` while Flink uses `1.7.7`: https://www.slf4j.org/api/org/slf4j/event/Level.html. Could you try updating to `1.7.15`?

After a rebase on #6729 and its followings, I think this pull request is ready to be reviewed.

cc @tillrohrmann and @uce .
@tillrohrmann What do you think of this way of handling?

I agree with @TisonKun. I think we cannot simply remove the tests but instead need to port them to the Flip-6 codebase. For example, the Yarn tests verify that the Yarn application master can be killed multiple times. Also the TaskManager failure test seems to be a valid one.

Thanks for your contribution @TisonKun. I think you merged at some point and now the git history is a bit messed up (some of your commits appear twice). Could you please clean this up. Otherwise, it is really hard for me to resolve the merge conflicts
hi @TisonKun and @tillrohrmann OK. So, what does "port to FLIP-6 code base" specifically mean? where is the "FLIP-6 code base" .Maybe I am missing some understanding of the context.
It seems that it is blocked by PR #6816 .

@tillrohrmann can roughly review the PR changes before Travis turns green. Considering that it is inseparable from [FLINK-10291](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-10291), I expect it to catch up with the release point of flink 1.7.

@klion26, I suggest we get back to Jira issue and discuss the approach. In general, if design is firstly described in Jira issue and there is a feedback from a committer, it simplifies and speeds up the review and merging. I would close this PR and open another one when there is an agreement in Jira issue about the implementation approach.
cc @kl0u
Now the tests only fail on timeouts.
@tillrohrmann sure

Porting to Flip-6 code base means to make it run with the Flip-6 code. There are some things which no longer work as a testing criterion (e.g. Flip-6 does not bring up TMs upfront). Ideally it is only about setting a different entrypoint but sometimes one need to adapt a bit more.
OK, I know. The "code base" misleads me.
yes, thanks for your solution @aljoscha . I will take a look about the failed test case because of timeout.

Thanks for the review @sunjincheng121!
I addressed your comments. 

I'd like to keep the `writeToSink` call in `LocalExecutor` for now and solve that in a follow up issue. We would need to register a temporary table, that cannot be removed anymore. There are plans to manage the catalog of the SQL Client into an `InMemoryExternalCatalog" that would make this easier.

I don't know why all the yarn tests have been unable to run successfully in my local (since I started participating in the Flink community), so I can only rely on Travis's exception detection while changing.
There is a merge conflict with `ResourceManager`.
@azagrebin ok, i'll close the PR.
@azagrebin I've updated the PR based on your comments, Please help reviewing it when you have time.
Hi @jihyun ! We are a bit busy now with the upcoming feature freeze. But I will review your PR as soon as possible.
@zentol the build is failing because of import of guava Futures, which are exposed by the cassandra driver, how to add exclusions to checkstyle?
@tillrohrmann fixed the conflicts.
I fixed the issue @igalshilman . I will wait once again for travis to give green and then I will merge. Thanks for the review.
LGTM 👍
Thanks for the review @ifndef-SleePy and @StefanRRichter. Merging this PR.
LGTM 👍
could you also close the JIRA? @chuanlei
ok thanks for info on the policy of versioning, so will this be merged into master ?

Could you please tell why it doesn't affect 1.4.0?
Can you write the fix against the current master? Also, please fix the test failures.

Hi @xccui can you help me to review this PR, I hope it can catch up with Flink 1.7.0's release point.

@fhueske 
Thanks for the review. Resolved all of the comments except unit tests for the checkpointing logic 
1) For the question of "instead of always reading as Row and from there converting to the other types?"

In Parquet's interface, a converter is needed for each type of result. Record can be convert to row by recursively put children in particular index, but Map has to do it with Key. To reduce code duplication, I use the row as intermediate representation. So type conversion can be put in sub class of ParquetInputFormat.

2) I will add unit test for checkpoint logic tomorrow night.
It affects 1.4 as well.

Hi @kent2171 ,

I had a look at the PR. I also wrote the same comment at the associated JIRA but I also include it here.

In general, as I said earlier, I like the idea of having Callbacks to notify when a file changes state.
As far as the design/implementation of the current PR is concerned, the following are my comments:

1) The `FileStateChangedCallback` seems to be pretty limiting, and probably designed with a specific usecase in mind. It assumes that the user would like to do sth with the underlying file system when the file changes state (e.g. write a special file). But other usecases may need to do a REST call, or update a DB, or in general communicate with another system.  

Given the above, I would suggest that the function should have an `open()` and a `close()` method which are called once and are responsible for allocating and freeing resources. The `open()` should potentially take the `flinkConfig` as argument and initialize any long-living resources, e.g. connections to databases, a connection to the filesystem, etc, and the close should be responsible for freeing them. This will allow the sink to accommodate a broader variety of usecases. Now for the methods themselves, I do not yet have a definite answer on what should be included as argument, but I would also include a `Context` as an argument. This will allow for future-proofing the method, as we will be able to add stuff in the `Context` if we want to expose more stuff in the future, rather than deprecating the already existing API and creating a new one.

2) IMPORTANT CONSIDERATIONS to keep in mind: all this is a "best-effort" reporting of state changes, as, for example, if a failure happens after transitioning a file to its "final" state, but before calling the hook, then you will never get the notification. This behavior is aligned with Flink's metric system, where metrics are not checkpointed. In our case though, the scenario described above is more tricky to accommodate as we are talking about integration with external systems.

Let me know what you think about the above!
LGTM 👍
LGTM 👍 Merging.

it seems the tests pass now 👍 

Please make sure to also:
 - rename the module to `flink-connector-kafka_${scala.binary.version}`
 - remove the `20` part from the classes
 - remove some unrelated leftover changes in the 0.11 connector
